abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Energy Delivery Services
            Project for Timor-Leste were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            high, Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned include: effective bank project support in
            fragile and conflict and or post conflict states requires
            intensive on the ground implementation support. The presence
            on the ground of more experienced staff can help to unblock
            many of the constraints that affected implementation.
            Ideally policy reform components should not be handled
            through investment lending, but where this was unavoidable
            because for example a policy action is closely related to an
            investment and or for lack of an alternative vehicle,
            borrower ownership and commitment should be assured at
            design stage and should be managed and monitored during
            implementation. The risk of Borrowers lack of commitment to
            the strategic planning and reform elements of the
            institutional and capacity building component were not
            explicitly identified at project design stage. Thus, in the
            end this component had to be dropped, although interestingly
            the Government of Timor-Leste (GoTL) is showing a keen
            interest to reform its power sector. As time progressed it
            became apparent that Ministry of Natural Resources, Minerals
            and Energy Policy (MNRMEP), Ministry of Infrastructure (MoI)
            and Electricidade de Timor-Lestes (EDTLs) senior
            management attention is focused on the large system
            expansion that the government had embarked on and reduced
            attention was being given the Energy Services Delivery
            Project (ESDP). Flexible partnership with Borrowers and the
            exercise of sound judgment are critical for achieving results.

repnme.cdata!:
Timor-Leste - Energy Services Delivery
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Energy Services
            Delivery Project are to stabilize the power services in
            Dili, by restoring or improving operational efficiency,
            reliability, safety and availability of the power supply,
            and to promote long-term sustainability of the power sector.
            This restructuring paper (RP) is in response to a request
            from the Government of Timor-Leste (GoTL) to use the
            remaining US$1.6 million of the International Development
            Association (IDA) Grant to scale up the successful component
            for rehabilitation and upgrading of the Dili power
            distribution system under part two of the project. The
            restructuring (level two) does not involve any change in the
            project development objective; but includes a minor
            reallocation among disbursement categories (one and half
            percent), some changes in outcome indicators, and a
            reallocation of a substantial portion of the grant funds
            from activities under parts 1, 3 and 4 of the project to
            part two. The GoTL's request was first communicated to
            the Bank's supervision mission in April 2011 and
            subsequently confirmed through a letter dated October 28,
            2011 from the Ministry of Finance (MoF). The letter also
            requested an extension of the Grant's closing date from
            December 31, 2011 to June 30, 2012. The Bank approved the
            extension of Grant's closing date to June 30, 2012 on
            December 21, 2011.

display_title.display_title:
Timor-Leste - Energy Services
            Delivery Project : restructuring  (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Timor-Leste - Energy Services Delivery
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Energy Services
            Delivery Project are to stabilize the power services in
            Dili, by restoring or improving operational efficiency,
            reliability, safety and availability of the power supply,
            and to promote long-term sustainability of the power sector.
            The borrower has also requested an extension of the grant
            closing date by six months from December 31, 2011 to June
            30, 2012 to allow enough time for completion of the
            rehabilitation and upgrading component of the project. This
            restructuring paper covers the extension of grant closing
            date. This will be the first extension of the grant's
            closing date. The borrower has submitted a satisfactory
            action plan for completion of the remaining activities
            within the six months extension period.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Energy Services
            Delivery Project in Timor are to stabilize the power
            services in Dili by restoring or improving operational
            efficiency, reliability, safety and availability of the
            power supply, and to promote long-term sustainability of the
            power sector. The project includes two main components: (a)
            investments; and (b) capacity building. The investment
            component would include: (i) emergency repair and
            maintenance of the Comoro Power Station; (ii) rehabilitation
            and upgrading of the power distribution system in Dili; and
            (iii) distribution of energy efficient light bulbs, and
            compact fluorescent lamps (CFLs). Timely repair of the power
            station and energy savings from the above investments will
            increase availability and reliability of power supply for
            both existing customers and new customers. A substantial
            capacity building component is proposed to support project
            implementation and for institutional and policy
            strengthening to help lay the groundwork for increased
            commercial orientation and long-term sustainability of the
            power sector.
